p: Acesulfame potassium (Acesulfame K, ACK) is a non-nutritive sweetener used in foods and beverages. It has a relative sweetness approximately 200 times that of sucrose. Indeed, 125 mg of ACK replaces approximately 25 g of sugar [ 111]. Once ingested, acesulfame potassium is rapidly and almost completely absorbed into the systemic circulation [ 114]. However, it remains not-metabolized and is excreted primarily via the kidneys into urine within 24 h of consumption [ 111, 114].
